Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 11:40AM DomeGal wrote: Just wanted to chime in....have more access to a computer since my son got a job after 4 years in the Marines!!  I chose having both breasts removed even though I was Hormone receptive and can take whatever new drug they have by the time I have finished chemo and radiation.  It is not an easy road, but I knew that I could NOT do this another 2-3 years down the road should I have developed cancer in the remaining breast....which although the pathology showed no cancer, did show pre-cancerous signs of cell development.  I also have 4 lymph nodes involved and am on a regimen of chemo and then radiation and then.....finally....reconstruction.  The first month I used to cry every time I took a shower and had to bandage myself and I noticed that my son would turn up his heavy metal each time I took a shower.  I can't say that I like what I see, but I know that I am heading towards being cancer-free and that is all I care about right now.  It is a long road and I have barely trod the path, but I feel confident that I made the right decisions along with my doctors.  If anyone has any info on the second chemo treatment and how that might affect me, I would be appreciative....the first treatment was good...no side effects except being tired.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed silverlady LISAMG

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 01:34PM DomeGal wrote: Hi all...had my bi-lateral mastectomy on 7/21 and came home the next day.  The hardest part is not being able to do anything and especially with my right arm...had 10 nodes removed with 4 showing cancer.  I am unable to decipher my pathology report which shows 1.2cm Grade 1, Tubular G2, Nuclear G2, Mitotic G1.  The other tumor was .7cm with same Grades, etc.  Lobular carcinoma in situ; Metastatic carcinoma in the axillary soft tissue (two foci), ER, PR, HEr2 Ki67 not submitted.  Today I went for a bone scan and will await those results.  Even though the left breast did not show cancer, it did have pre-cancerous cells and "odd" looking material so I really feel that I did the right thing removing both.  I am afraid, but glad that this portion is over...not so much pain as just being uncomfortable and not being able to lay on either side!  I wish all of you well as we continue on this journey that none of us asked for, but will fight with all of our might against.
Posts.Title: July surgery karina_il DomeGal

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 02:25PM DomeGal wrote: I too was just diagnosed with 4 tumors in one breast and one lymph node involved and I know that you are scared, but it is not the end of the world by any stretch.  I had a CT scan last week and I don't have cancer anywhere else.  I am having surgery on July 21st and I have elected to remove both breasts even though the doctor said that I only had to remove the affected breast.  I am having chemo and radiation and I am afraid, but hopeful.  I elected to remove both because I do not want to go through this again years down the road.  I have both breast cancer and ovarian cancer on both sides of my family.  Try to stay positive and find a support group in your area.  You will get through this...I cry every day, but I have been helped by letting people know...you need people to lean on and help you.
